title: Welcome!
text: We welcome all early career researchers across the UK DRI tackling dementia with data science to join us at our first solo symposium, where we aim to explore together the rapidly expanding opportunities presented by data-driven approaches in combating one of the greatest challenges of our time.

title: Welcome!
text:
Venue

International Students House, 229 Great Portland St, London W1B 1PF

title: All the links!
text:
Welcome to link central!

Survey
We really want to know more about the informatics community to help us understand what will be most useful for us to do as a committee.
A huge thanks to those who’ve already filled it in, but for those who haven’t please find it here: https://portal.ukdri.ac.uk/news/are-you-using-informatics-in-your-uk-dri-research


DRI GitHub
The DRI has a GitHub organisation, and we’d love to see folk using for sharing their code. This meeting has also has a repo which includes this site!

title: All the links!
text:
Welcome to link central!
The agenda for the symposium can be found here.

Survey
We really want to know more about the informatics community to help us understand what will be most useful for us to do as a committee.
A huge thanks to those who’ve already filled it in, but for those who haven’t please find it here: https://portal.ukdri.ac.uk/news/are-you-using-informatics-in-your-uk-dri-research


DRI GitHub
The DRI has a GitHub organisation, and we’d love to see folk using for sharing their code. This meeting has also has a repo which includes this site!


Slides & Posters
Talks that have been made available can be found on the repo here, and posters here.

title: Welcome!
text:
Agenda
The program can be found here.
This conference will bring together experts in bioinformatics, imaging, machine learning and statistics, to foster an inclusive interdisciplinary dialogue aimed at accelerating progress in your dementia research. A chance to network and collaborate with like-minded colleagues, forging new partnerships and uncovering opportunities for cross-pollination and career development. Share your research via a short talk or poster and engage in thought-provoking technical discussions.
The “Integrative Informatics for Targeting Dementia” session represents a chance for us to gather and learn about what others in the UK DRI informatics community are doing and how new collaborations may benefit your research in years to come.

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Discussion groups




Each table has a topic to discuss for 10 minutes
Please add your thoughts on the topic to the shared document: https://hackmd.io/@Coconut1019/BJJYscMY6/edit

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Code Review




Join the team!
How does the community want it to be used?

Quick second pair of eyes on code snippet?
Methodological advice (QC cutoff, etc)?
Full review of project codebase?

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Code Review continued




Acknowledgements for review?

GitHub has metrics
Authorship? Establish group rules, or discuss ad-hoc?
Minimal acknowledgement in GitHub Contributors file for reviewers?

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Proposed workflow

Make a repo on DRI GitHub Org (perhaps using the template
Write and publish a registered report outlining the project
Gather/analyse data

Make ADDI workspace?
Use existing pipelines if applicable (Nextflow)
Containerise software environment (probably at end of project)

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Proposed workflow continued




Publish all the things!

Pre-print -> diamond open access
Data on relevant public repositories + ADDI?
generate DOI for code repo via Zenodo

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Example slide
Here is some text. The font is Arial (hex: #00326e). Here is another sentence with bold and italic text. Here is an example reference: (Baker and Escott-Price 2020)




Here is a bullet point
The font used is Arial and font size is 18px
Bullets are coloured hex: #0ac8ff

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Incremental content
Hi!

Use . . . to separate content as an incremental slide!

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Diagrams with Mermaid!
Read about how to create a diagram in this post by Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel.





flowchart LR
  A[qmd] --> B(Knitr)
  A[qmd] --> C(Jupyter)
  B(Knitr) --> D[md]
  C(Jupyter) --> D[md]
  D[md] --> E(pandoc)
  E(pandoc) --> F(HTML)
  E(pandoc) --> G(PDF)
  E(pandoc) --> H(Word)
  E(pandoc) --> I{and more}


Figure 1: How Quarto orchestrates rendering of documents: start with a qmd file, use the Knitr or Jupyter engine to perform the computations and convert it to an md file, then use Pandoc to convert to various file formats including HTML, PDF, and Word.

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Exporting into PDF
You can use the function pagedown::chrome_print() to print the HTML version into a PDF!
pagedown::chrome_print("path-to-file.html")

title: Exploring Reproducibility
text:
Thanks for listening!




Here’s to making science slightly less crap!
Please get in touch about anything reproducibility related (or just just say hi :) - bernardo-harringtong@cardiff.ac.uk
Questions?
